speaker: Narrator

text:
The daughters of kings are among your noble ladies.
The queen takes her place at your right hand
and wears gold from Ophir.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, daughter! Look closely!
Turn your ear toward me.
Forget your people, and forget your father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king longs for your beauty.
He is your Lord.
Worship him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Tyre, the richest people,
want to win your favor with a gift.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The daughter of the king is glorious inside the palace.
Her dress is embroidered with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wearing a colorful gown, she is brought to the king.
Her bridesmaids follow her.
They will be brought to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With joy and delight they are brought in.
They enter the palace of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your sons will take the place of your father.
You will make them princes over the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will cause your name to be remembered throughout every generation.
That is why the nations will give thanks to you forever and ever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is our refuge and strength,
an ever-present help in times of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why we are not afraid
even when the earth quakes
or the mountains topple into the depths of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Water roars and foams,
and mountains shake at the surging waves. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a river
whose streams bring joy to the city of God,
the holy place where the Most High lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is in that city.
It cannot fall.
God will help it at the break of dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nations are in turmoil, and kingdoms topple.
The earth melts at the sound of God’s voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Armies is with us.
The God of Jacob is our stronghold. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, see the works of the Lord,
the devastation he has brought to the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He puts an end to wars all over the earth.
He breaks an archer’s bow.
He cuts spears in two.
He burns chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let go of your concerns!
Then you will know that I am God.
I rule the nations.
I rule the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of Armies is with us.
The God of Jacob is our stronghold. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Clap your hands, all you people.
Shout to God with a loud, joyful song.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We must fear the Lord, the Most High.
He is the great king of the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brings people under our authority
and puts nations under our feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chooses our inheritance for us,
the pride of Jacob, whom he loved. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has gone up with a joyful shout.
The Lord has gone up with the sound of a ram’s horn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make music to praise God.
Play music for him!
Make music to praise our king.
Play music for him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is the king of the whole earth.
Make your best music for him!
speaker: Narrator

text:
God rules the nations.
He sits upon his holy throne.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The influential people from the nations gather together
as the people of the God of Abraham.
The rulers of the earth belong to God.
He rules everything.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is great.
He should be highly praised.
His holy mountain is in the city of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its beautiful peak is the joy of the whole earth.
Mount Zion is on the northern ridge.
It is the city of the great king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is in its palaces.
He has proved that he is a stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kings have gathered.
They marched together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they saw Mount Zion,
they were astonished.
They were terrified and ran away in fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trembling seized them
like the trembling that a woman experiences during labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the east wind you smash the ships of Tarshish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The things we had only heard about, we have now seen
in the city of the Lord of Armies,
in the city of our God.
God makes Zion stand firm forever. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text: Inside your temple we carefully reflect on your mercy, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like your name, O God,
your praise reaches to the ends of the earth.
Your right hand is filled with righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let Mount Zion be glad
and the cities of Judah rejoice
because of your judgments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Walk around Zion.
Go around it.
Count its towers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Examine its embankments.
Walk through its palaces.
Then you can tell the next generation,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This God is our God forever and ever.
He will lead us beyond death.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to this, all you people.
Open your ears, all who live in the world—
speaker: Narrator

text:
common people and important ones,
rich people and poor ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My mouth will speak wise sayings,
the insights I have carefully considered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will turn my attention to a proverb.
I will explain my riddle with the music of a lyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should I be afraid in times of trouble,
when slanderers surround me with evil?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They trust their riches
and brag about their abundant wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one can ever buy back another person
or pay God a ransom for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The price to be paid for his soul is too costly.
He must always give up
speaker: Narrator

text: in order to live forever and never see the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, one can see that wise people die,
that foolish and stupid people meet the same end.
They leave their riches to others.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although they named their lands after themselves,
their graves  have become their homes for ages to come,
their dwelling places throughout every generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But mortals will not continue here with what they treasure.
They are like animals that die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the final outcome for fools and their followers
who are delighted by what they say: Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like sheep, they are driven to hell
with death as their shepherd.
(Decent people will rule them in the morning.)
Their forms will decay in the grave,
far away from their comfortable homes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God will buy me back from the power of hell
because he will take me. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be afraid when someone becomes rich,
when the greatness of his house increases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not take anything with him when he dies.
His greatness cannot follow him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even though he blesses himself while he is alive
(and they praise you when you do well for yourself),
speaker: Narrator

text:
he must join the generation of his ancestors,
who will never see light again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mortals, with what they treasure, still don’t have understanding.
They are like animals that die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord, the only true God, has spoken.
He has summoned the earth
from where the sun rises to where it sets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God shines from Zion,
the perfection of beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our God will come and will not remain silent.
A devouring fire is in front of him
and a raging storm around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He summons heaven and earth to judge his people:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Gather around me, my godly people
who have made a pledge to me through sacrifices.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heavens announce his righteousness
because God is the judge. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen, my people, and I will speak.
Listen, Israel, and I will testify against you:
I am God, your God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am not criticizing you for your sacrifices or burnt offerings,
which are always in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will not accept another young bull from your household
or a single male goat from your pens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every creature in the forest,
even the cattle on a thousand hills, is mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know every bird in the mountains.
Everything that moves in the fields is mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I were hungry, I would not tell you,
because the world and all that it contains are mine.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do I eat the meat of bulls or drink the blood of goats?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bring your thanks to God as a sacrifice,
and keep your vows to the Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Call on me in times of trouble.
I will rescue you, and you will honor me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God says to wicked people,
“How dare you quote my decrees
and mouth my promises!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You hate discipline.
You toss my words behind you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you see a thief, you want to make friends with him.
You keep company with people who commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You let your mouth say anything evil.
Your tongue plans deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You sit and talk against your own brother.
You slander your own mother’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you did these things, I remained silent.
That made you think I was like you.
I will argue my point with you
and lay it all out for you to see.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Consider this, you people who forget God.
Otherwise, I will tear you to pieces,
and there will be no one left to rescue you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever offers thanks as a sacrifice honors me.
I will let everyone who continues in my way
see the salvation that comes from God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have pity on me, O God, in keeping with your mercy.
In keeping with your unlimited compassion, wipe out my rebellious acts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wash me thoroughly from my guilt,
and cleanse me from my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I admit that I am rebellious.
My sin is always in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have sinned against you, especially you.
I have done what you consider evil.
So you hand down justice when you speak,
and you are blameless when you judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, I was born guilty.
I was a sinner when my mother conceived me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet, you desire truth and sincerity.
Deep down inside me you teach me wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Purify me from sin with hyssop, and I will be clean.
Wash me, and I will be whiter than snow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me hear sounds of joy and gladness.
Let the bones that you have broken dance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide your face from my sins,
and wipe out all that I have done wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Create a clean heart in me, O God,
and renew a faithful spirit within me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not force me away from your presence,
and do not take your Holy Spirit from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Restore the joy of your salvation to me,
and provide me with a spirit of willing obedience.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will teach your ways to those who are rebellious,
and sinners will return to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from the guilt of murder,
O God, my savior.
Let my tongue sing joyfully about your righteousness!
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, open my lips,
and my mouth will tell about your praise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are not happy with any sacrifice.
Otherwise, I would offer one to you.
You are not pleased with burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sacrifice pleasing to God is a broken spirit.
O God, you do not despise a broken and sorrowful heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Favor Zion with your goodness.
Rebuild the walls of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will be pleased with sacrifices offered in the right spirit—
with burnt offerings and whole burnt offerings.
Young bulls will be offered on your altar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you brag about the evil you’ve done, you hero?
The mercy of God lasts all day long!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your tongue makes up threats.
It’s like a sharp razor, you master of deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You prefer evil to good.
You prefer lying to speaking the truth. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text: You love every destructive accusation, you deceitful tongue!
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God will ruin you forever.
He will grab you and drag you out of your tent.
He will pull your roots out of this world of the living. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteous people will see this and be struck with fear.
They will laugh at you and say,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look at this person who refused to make God his fortress!
Instead, he trusted his great wealth
and became strong through his greed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I am like a large olive tree in God’s house.
I trust the mercy of God forever and ever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will give thanks to you forever
for what you have done.
In the presence of your godly people,
I will wait with hope in your good name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Godless fools say in their hearts,
“There is no God.”
They are corrupt.
They do disgusting things.
There is no one who does good things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God looks down from heaven on Adam’s descendants
to see if there is anyone who acts wisely,
if there is anyone who seeks help from God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone has fallen away.
Together they have become rotten to the core.
No one, not even one person, does good things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are all those troublemakers,
those who devour my people as if they were devouring food,
so ignorant that they do not call on God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
There they are—panic-stricken—
but there was no reason to panic,
because God has scattered the bones
of those who set up camp against you.
You put them to shame.
After all, God has rejected them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only salvation for Israel would come from Zion!
When God restores the fortunes of his people,
Jacob will rejoice.
Israel will be glad.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, save me by your name,
and defend me with your might.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, hear my prayer,
and open your ears to the words from my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strangers have attacked me.
Ruthless people seek my life.
They do not think about God. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is my helper!
The Lord is the provider for my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies spy on me.
Pay them back with evil.
Destroy them with your truth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make a sacrifice to you along with a freewill offering.
I will give thanks to your good name, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your name rescues me from every trouble.
My eyes will gloat over my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Open your ears to my prayer, O God.
Do not hide from my plea for mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay attention to me, and answer me.
My thoughts are restless, and I am confused
speaker: Narrator

text:
because my enemy shouts at me
and a wicked person persecutes me.
They bring misery crashing down on me,
and they attack me out of anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart is in turmoil.
The terrors of death have seized me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear and trembling have overcome me.
Horror has overwhelmed me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, “If only I had wings like a dove—
I would fly away and find rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, I would run far away.
I would stay in the desert. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would hurry to find shelter
from the raging wind and storm.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Completely confuse their language, O Lord,
because I see violence and conflict in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Day and night they go around on top of the city walls.
Trouble and misery are everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Destruction is everywhere.
Oppression and fraud never leave the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If an enemy had insulted me,
then I could bear it.
If someone who hated me had attacked me,
then I could hide from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it is you, my equal,
my best friend,
one I knew so well!
speaker: Narrator

text:
We used to talk to each other in complete confidence
and walk into God’s house with the festival crowds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let death suddenly take wicked people!
Let them go into the grave while they are still alive,
because evil lives in their homes as well as in their hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I call on God,
and the Lord saves me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Morning, noon, and night I complain and groan,
and he listens to my voice.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God will listen.
The one who has sat enthroned from the beginning
will deal with them. Selah
They never change. They never fear God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My best friend has betrayed his friends.
He has broken his solemn promise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His speech is smoother than butter,
but there is war in his heart.
His words are more soothing than oil,
but they are like swords ready to attack.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn your burdens over to the Lord,
and he will take care of you.
He will never let the righteous person stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you, O God, will throw wicked people into the deepest pit.
Bloodthirsty and deceitful people will not live out half their days.
But I will trust you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have pity on me, O God, because people are harassing me.
All day long warriors oppress me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All day long my enemies spy on me.
They harass me.
There are so many fighting against me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when I am afraid, I still trust you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I praise God’s word.
I trust God.
I am not afraid.
What can mere flesh and blood do to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
All day long my enemies twist my words.
Their every thought is an evil plan against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They attack, and then they hide.
They watch my every step as they wait to take my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With the wrong they do, can they escape?
O God, angrily make the nations fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
(You have kept a record of my wanderings.
Put my tears in your bottle.
They are already in your book.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then my enemies will retreat when I call to you.
This I know: God is on my side.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I praise God’s word.
I praise the Lord’s word.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I trust God.
I am not afraid.
What can mortals do to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am bound by my vows to you, O God.
I will keep my vows by offering songs of thanksgiving to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have rescued me from death.
You have kept my feet from stumbling
so that I could walk in your presence, in the light of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have pity on me, O God. Have pity on me,
because my soul takes refuge in you.
I will take refuge in the shadow of your wings
until destructive storms pass by.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I call to God Most High,
to the God who does everything for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sends his help from heaven and saves me.
He disgraces the one who is harassing me. Selah
God sends his mercy and his truth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul is surrounded by lions.
I must lie down with man-eating lions.
Their teeth are spears and arrows.
Their tongues are sharp swords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May you be honored above the heavens, O God.
Let your glory extend over the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies spread out a net to catch me.
(My soul is bowed down.)
They dug a pit to trap me,
but then they fell into it. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart is confident, O God.
My heart is confident.
I want to sing and make music.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wake up, my soul! 
Wake up, harp and lyre!
I want to wake up at dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I want to give thanks to you among the people, O Lord.
I want to make music to praise you among the nations
speaker: Narrator

text:
because your mercy is as high as the heavens.
Your truth reaches the skies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May you be honored above the heavens, O God.
Let your glory extend over the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you rulers really give fair verdicts?
Do you judge Adam’s descendants fairly?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No, you invent new crimes on earth,
and your hands spread violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even inside the womb wicked people are strangers to God.
From their birth liars go astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have poisonous venom like snakes.
They are like a deaf cobra that shuts its ears
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that it cannot hear the voice of a snake charmer
or of anyone trained to cast spells.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, knock the teeth out of their mouths.
Break the young lions’ teeth, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them disappear like water that drains away.
When they aim their bows, let their arrows miss the target.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them become like a snail that leaves behind a slimy trail
or like a stillborn child who never sees the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let God sweep them away
faster than a cooking pot is heated by burning twigs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteous people will rejoice when they see God take revenge.
They will wash their feet in the blood of wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then people will say,
“Righteous people certainly have a reward.
There is a God who judges on earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from my enemies, O my God.
Protect me from those who attack me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from troublemakers.
Save me from bloodthirsty people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They lie in ambush for me right here!
Fierce men attack me, O Lord,
but not because of any disobedience,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or any sin, or any guilt on my part.
They hurry to take positions against me.
Wake up, and help me; see for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Armies, God of Israel,
arise to punish all the nations.
Have no pity on any traitors. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
They return in the evening.
They howl like dogs.
They prowl the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See what pours out of their mouths—
swords from their lips!
They think, “Who will hear us?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, you laugh at them.
You make fun of all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my strength, I watch for you!
God is my stronghold, my merciful God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
God will come to meet me.
He will let me gloat over those who spy on me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not kill them.
Otherwise, my people may forget.
Make them wander aimlessly by your power.
Bring them down, O Lord, our shield,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because of the sins from their mouths
and the words on their lips.
Let them be trapped by their own arrogance
because they speak curses and lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Destroy them in your rage.
Destroy them until not one of them is left.
Then they will know that God rules Jacob
to the ends of the earth. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
They return in the evening.
They howl like dogs.
They prowl the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They wander around to find something to eat.
If they are not full enough,
they will stay all night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will sing about your strength.
In the morning I will joyfully sing about your mercy.
You have been my stronghold
and a place of safety in times of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my strength, I will make music to praise you!
God is my stronghold, my merciful God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you have rejected us.
You have broken down our defenses.
You have been angry.
Restore us!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You made the land quake.
You split it wide open.
Heal the cracks in it
because it is falling apart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have made your people experience hardships.
You have given us wine that makes us stagger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet, you have raised a flag for those who fear you
so that they can rally to it
when attacked by bows and arrows. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Save us with your powerful hand, and answer us
so that those who are dear to you may be rescued.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has promised the following through his holiness:
“I will triumph!
I will divide Shechem.
I will measure the valley of Succoth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead is mine.
Manasseh is mine.
Ephraim is the helmet on my head.
Judah is my scepter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moab is my washtub.
I will throw my shoe over Edom.
I will shout in triumph over Philistia.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who will bring me into the fortified city?
Who will lead me to Edom?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Isn’t it you, O God, who rejected us?
Isn’t it you, O God, who refused to accompany our armies?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give us help against the enemy
because human assistance is worthless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With God we will display great strength.
He will trample our enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to my cry for help, O God.
Pay attention to my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the ends of the earth, I call to you
when I begin to lose heart.
Lead me to the rock that is high above me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have been my refuge,
a tower of strength against the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would like to be a guest in your tent forever
and to take refuge under the protection of your wings. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you have heard my vows.
You have given me the inheritance
that belongs to those who fear your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Add days upon days to the life of the king.
May his years endure throughout every generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he sit enthroned in the presence of God forever.
May mercy and truth protect him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will make music to praise your name forever,
as I keep my vows day after day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul waits calmly for God alone.
My salvation comes from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone is my rock and my savior—my stronghold.
I cannot be severely shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long will all of you attack a person?
How long will you try to murder him,
as though he were a leaning wall or a sagging fence?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They plan to force him out of his high position.
They are happy to lie.
They bless with their mouths,
but in their hearts they curse. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wait calmly for God alone, my soul,
because my hope comes from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone is my rock and my savior—my stronghold.
I cannot be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My salvation and my glory depend on God.
God is the rock of my strength, my refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust him at all times, you people.
Pour out your hearts in his presence.
God is our refuge. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Common people are only a whisper in the wind.
Important people are only a delusion.
When all of them are weighed on a scale, they amount to nothing.
They are less than a whisper in the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not count on extortion to make you rich.
Do not hope to gain anything through robbery.
When riches increase, do not depend on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has spoken once.
I have heard it said twice:
“Power belongs to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mercy belongs to you, O Lord.
You reward a person based on what he has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you are my God.
At dawn I search for you.
My soul thirsts for you.
My body longs for you
in a dry, parched land where there is no water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I look for you in the holy place
to see your power and your glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lips will praise you
because your mercy is better than life itself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I will thank you as long as I live.
I will lift up my hands to pray in your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You satisfy my soul with the richest foods.
My mouth will sing your praise with joyful lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As I lie on my bed, I remember you.
Through the long hours of the night, I think about you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have been my help.
In the shadow of your wings, I sing joyfully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul clings to you.
Your right hand supports me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But those who try to destroy my life
will go into the depths of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be cut down by swords.
Their dead bodies will be left as food for jackals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the king will find joy in God.
Everyone who takes an oath by God will brag,
but the mouths of liars will be shut.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear my voice, O God, when I complain.
Protect my life from a terrifying enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide me from the secret plots of criminals,
from the mob of troublemakers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sharpen their tongues like swords.
They aim bitter words like arrows
speaker: Narrator

text:
to shoot at innocent people from their hiding places.
They shoot at them suddenly, without any fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They encourage one another in their evil plans.
They talk about setting traps and say,
“Who can see them?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They search for the perfect crime and say,
“We have perfected a foolproof scheme!”
Human nature and the human heart are a mystery!
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God will shoot them with an arrow.
Suddenly, they will be struck dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will trip over their own tongues.
Everyone who sees them will shake his head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone will be afraid and conclude,
“This is an act of God!”
They will learn from what he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteous people will find joy in the Lord and take refuge in him.
Everyone whose motives are decent will be able to brag.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are praised with silence in Zion, O God,
and vows made to you must be kept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are the one who hears prayers.
Everyone will come to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Various sins overwhelm me.
You are the one who forgives our rebellious acts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed is the person you choose
and invite to live with you in your courtyards.
We will be filled with good food from your house,
from your holy temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You answer us with awe-inspiring acts done in righteousness,
O God, our savior,
the hope of all the ends of the earth and of the most distant sea,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the one who set the mountains in place with his strength,
the one who is clothed with power,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the one who calms the roar of the seas,
their crashing waves,
and the uproar of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who live at the ends of the earth are in awe of your miraculous signs.
The lands of the morning sunrise and evening sunset sing joyfully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You take care of the earth, and you water it.
You make it much richer than it was.
(The river of God is filled with water.)
You provide grain for them.
Indeed, you even prepare the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You drench plowed fields with rain
and level their clumps of soil.
You soften them with showers
and bless what grows in them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You crown the year with your goodness,
and richness overflows wherever you are.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pastures in the desert overflow with richness.
The hills are surrounded with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pastures are covered with flocks.
The valleys are carpeted with grain.
All of them shout triumphantly. Indeed, they sing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shout happily to God, all the earth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make music to praise the glory of his name.
Make his praise glorious.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to God,
“How awe-inspiring are your deeds!
Your power is so great that your enemies will cringe in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The whole earth will worship you.
It will make music to praise you.
It will make music to praise your name.” Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come and see what God has done—
his awe-inspiring deeds for Adam’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He turned the sea into dry land.
They crossed the river on foot.
We rejoiced because of what he did there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rules forever with his might.
His eyes watch the nations.
Rebels will not be able to oppose him. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thank our God, you nations.
Make the sound of his praise heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has kept us alive
and has not allowed us to fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have tested us, O God.
You have refined us in the same way silver is refined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have trapped us in a net.
You have laid burdens on our backs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You let people ride over our heads.
We went through fire and water,
but then you brought us out and refreshed us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will come into your temple with burnt offerings.
I will keep my vows to you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the vows made by my lips and spoken by my own mouth
when I was in trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will offer you a sacrifice of fattened livestock for burnt offerings
with the smoke from rams.
I will offer cattle and goats. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come and listen, all who fear God,
and I will tell you what he has done for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With my mouth I cried out to him.
High praise was on my tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I had thought about doing anything sinful,
the Lord would not have listened to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God has heard me.
He has paid attention to my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thanks be to God,
who has not rejected my prayer
or taken away his mercy from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God have pity on us and bless us!
May he smile on us. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then your ways will be known on earth,
your salvation throughout all nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let everyone give thanks to you, O God.
Let everyone give thanks to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the nations be glad and sing joyfully
because you judge everyone with justice
and guide the nations on the earth. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the people give thanks to you, O God.
Let all the people give thanks to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth has yielded its harvest.
May God, our God, bless us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God bless us,
and may all the ends of the earth worship him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God will arise.
His enemies will be scattered.
Those who hate him will flee from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blow them away like smoke.
Let wicked people melt in God’s presence like wax next to a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But let righteous people rejoice.
Let them celebrate in God’s presence.
Let them overflow with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing to God; make music to praise his name.
Make a highway for him to ride through the deserts.
The Lord is his name.
Celebrate in his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God who is in his holy dwelling place
is the father of the fatherless and the defender of widows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God places lonely people in families.
He leads prisoners out of prison into productive lives,
but rebellious people must live in an unproductive land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, when you went in front of your people,
when you marched through the desert, Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
the earth quaked and the sky poured
in the presence of the God of Sinai,
in the presence of the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You watered the land with plenty of rain, O God.
You refreshed it when your land was exhausted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your flock settled there.
Out of your goodness, O God,
you provided for oppressed people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord gives instructions.
The women who announce the good news are a large army.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, “The kings of the armies flee; they run away.
The women who remained at home will divide the goods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though you stayed among the sheep pens,
you will be like the wings of a dove covered with silver, its feathers with yellow gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meanwhile, the Almighty was still scattering kings there
like snow falling on Mount Zalmon.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountain of Bashan is the mountain of God.
The mountain of Bashan is the mountain with many peaks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you look with envy, you mountains with many peaks,
at the mountain where God has chosen to live?
Certainly, the Lord will live there forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The chariots of God are twenty thousand in number,
thousands upon thousands.
The Lord is among them.
The God of Sinai is in his holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You went to the highest place.
You took prisoners captive.
You received gifts from people,
even from rebellious people, so that the Lord God may live there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thanks be to the Lord,
who daily carries our burdens for us.
God is our salvation. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our God is the God of victories.
The Almighty Lord is our escape from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, God will crush the heads of his enemies
and destroy even the hair on the heads
of those who continue to be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said, “I will bring them back from Bashan.
I will bring them back from the depths of the sea
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that you, my people, may bathe  your feet in blood
and the tongues of your dogs
may lick the blood of your enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your festival processions, O God, can be seen by everyone.
They are the processions for my God, my king, into the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The singers are in front.
The musicians are behind them.
The young women beating tambourines are between them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thank God, the Lord, the source of Israel, with the choirs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Benjamin, the youngest, is leading them,
next the leaders of Judah with their noisy crowds,
then the leaders of Zebulun,
then the leaders of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your God has decided you will be strong.
Display your strength, O God,
as you have for us before.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kings will bring you gifts
because of your temple high above Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Threaten the beast who is among the cattails,
the herd of bulls with the calves of the nations,
until it humbles itself with pieces of silver.
Scatter the people who find joy in war.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ambassadors will come from Egypt.
Sudan will stretch out its hands to God in prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You kingdoms of the world, sing to God.
Make music to praise the Lord. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
God rides through the ancient heaven, the highest heaven.
Listen! He makes his voice heard, his powerful voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Acknowledge the power of God.
His majesty is over Israel, and his power is in the skies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God, the God of Israel, is awe-inspiring in his holy place.
He gives strength and power to his people.
Thanks be to God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Save me, O God!
The water is already up to my neck!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am sinking in deep mud.
There is nothing to stand on.
I am in deep water.
A flood is sweeping me away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am exhausted from crying for help.
My throat is hoarse.
My eyes are strained from looking for my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate me for no reason
outnumber the hairs on my head.
Those who want to destroy me are mighty.
They have no reason to be my enemies.
I am forced to pay back what I did not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you know my stupidity,
and the things of which I am guilty are not hidden from you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let those who wait with hope for you
be put to shame because of me, O Almighty Lord of Armies.
Do not let those who come to you for help
be humiliated because of me, O God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, for your sake I have endured insults.
Humiliation has covered my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have become a stranger to my own brothers,
a foreigner to my mother’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, devotion for your house has consumed me,
and the insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I cried and fasted, but I was insulted for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I dressed myself in sackcloth, but I became the object of ridicule.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who sit at the gate gossip about me,
and drunkards make up songs about me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May my prayer come to you at an acceptable time, O Lord.
O God, out of the greatness of your mercy,
answer me with the truth of your salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from the mud.
Do not let me sink into it.
I want to be rescued from those who hate me
and from the deep water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let floodwaters sweep me away.
Do not let the ocean swallow me up,
or the pit close its mouth over me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer me, O Lord, because your mercy is good.
Out of your unlimited compassion, turn to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am in trouble, so do not hide your face from me.
Answer me quickly!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come close, and defend my soul.
Set me free because of my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You know that I have been insulted, put to shame, and humiliated.
All my opponents are in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Insults have broken my heart, and I am sick.
I looked for sympathy, but there was none.
I looked for people to comfort me, but I found no one.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They poisoned my food,
and when I was thirsty, they gave me vinegar to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the table set for them become a trap
and a snare for their friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their vision become clouded so that they cannot see.
Let their thighs continually shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour your rage on them.
Let your burning anger catch up with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their camp be deserted
and their tents empty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They persecute the one you have struck,
and they talk about the pain of those you have wounded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Charge them with one crime after another.
Do not let them be found innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their names be erased from the Book of Life.
Do not let them be listed with righteous people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am suffering and in pain.
Let your saving power protect me, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I want to praise God’s name with a song.
I want to praise his great name with a song of thanksgiving.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This will please the Lord more than sacrificing an ox
or a bull with horns and hoofs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oppressed people will see this and rejoice.
May the hearts of those who look to God for help be refreshed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord listens to needy people.
He does not despise his own who are in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let heaven and earth, the seas, and everything that moves in them, praise him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When God saves Zion, he will rebuild the cities of Judah.
His servants will live there and take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of his servants will inherit it.
Those who love him will live there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come quickly to rescue me, O God!
Come quickly to help me, O Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let those who seek my life
be confused and put to shame.
Let those who want my downfall
be turned back and disgraced.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let those who say, “Aha! Aha!”
be turned back because of their own shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let all who seek you rejoice and be glad because of you.
Let those who love your salvation continually say,
“God is great!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I am oppressed and needy.
O God, come to me quickly.
You are my help and my savior.
O Lord, do not delay!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have taken refuge in you, O Lord.
Never let me be put to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me and free me because of your righteousness.
Turn your ear toward me, and save me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be a rock on which I may live,
a place where I may always go.
You gave the order to save me!
Indeed, you are my rock and my fortress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My God, free me from the hands of a wicked person,
from the grasp of one who is cruel and unjust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are my hope, O Almighty Lord.
You have been my confidence ever since I was young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I depended on you before I was born.
You took me from my mother’s womb.
My songs of praise constantly speak about you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have become an example to many people,
but you are my strong refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My mouth is filled with your praise,
with your glory all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not reject me when I am old
or abandon me when I lose my strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies talk about me.
They watch me as they plot to take my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, “God has abandoned him.
Pursue him and grab him because there is no one to rescue him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, do not be so distant from me.
O my God, come quickly to help me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let those who accuse me come to a shameful end.
Let those who want my downfall be covered
with disgrace and humiliation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will always have hope.
I will praise you more and more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My mouth will tell about your righteousness,
about your salvation all day long.
Even then, it is more than I can understand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will come with the mighty deeds of the Almighty Lord.
I will praise your righteousness, yours alone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you have taught me ever since I was young,
and I still talk about the miracles you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even when I am old and gray, do not abandon me, O God.
Let me live to tell the people of this age
what your strength has accomplished,
to tell about your power to all who will come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your righteousness reaches to the heavens, O God.
You have done great things.
O God, who is like you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have made me endure many terrible troubles.
You restore me to life again.
You bring me back from the depths of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You comfort me and make me greater than ever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because of your faithfulness, O my God,
even I will give thanks to you as I play on a lyre.
I will make music with a harp to praise you, O Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lips will sing with joy when I make music to praise you.
My soul, which you have rescued, also will sing joyfully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My tongue will tell about your righteousness all day long,
because those who wanted my downfall
have been disgraced and put to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, give the king your justice
and the king’s son  your righteousness
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that he may judge your people with righteousness
and your oppressed people with justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the mountains bring peace to the people
and the hills bring righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he grant justice to the people who are oppressed.
May he save the children of needy people
and crush their oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May they fear you as long as the sun and moon shine—
throughout every generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he be like rain that falls on freshly cut grass,
like showers that water the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May righteous people blossom in his day.
May there be unlimited peace until the moon no longer shines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he rule from sea to sea,
from the Euphrates River to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the people of the desert kneel in front of him.
May his enemies lick the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May the kings from Tarshish and the islands bring presents.
May the kings from Sheba and Seba bring gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May all kings worship him.
May all nations serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will rescue the needy person who cries for help
and the oppressed person who has no one’s help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will have pity on the poor and needy
and will save the lives of the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will rescue them from oppression and violence.
Their blood will be precious in his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he live long.
May the gold from Sheba be given to him.
May the people pray for him continually.
May they praise him all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May there be plenty of grain in the land.
May it wave in the breeze on the mountaintops,
its fruit like the treetops of Lebanon.
May those from the city flourish like the grass on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May his name endure forever.
May his name continue as long as the sun shines.
May all nations be blessed through him and call him blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thank the Lord God, the God of Israel,
who alone does miracles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thanks be to his glorious name forever.
May the whole earth be filled with his glory.
Amen and amen!
speaker: Narrator

text: The prayers by David, son of Jesse, end here.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is truly good to Israel,
to those whose lives are pure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But my feet had almost stumbled.
They had almost slipped
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I was envious of arrogant people
when I saw the prosperity that wicked people enjoy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They suffer no pain.
Their bodies are healthy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have no drudgery in their lives like ordinary people.
They are not plagued with problems like others.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why they wear arrogance like a necklace
and acts of violence like clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their eyes peer out from their fat faces,
and their imaginations run wild.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ridicule.
They speak maliciously.
They speak arrogantly about oppression.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They verbally attack heaven,
and they order people around on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why God’s people turn to wickedness
and swallow their words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then wicked people ask, “What does God know?”
“Does the Most High know anything?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look how wicked they are!
They never have a worry.
They grow more and more wealthy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’ve received no reward for keeping my life pure
and washing my hands of any blame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m plagued with problems all day long,
and every morning my punishment begins again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I had said, “I will continue to talk like that,”
I would have betrayed God’s people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But when I tried to understand this,
it was too difficult for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Only when I came into God’s holy place
did I finally understand what would happen to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You put them in slippery places
and make them fall into ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are suddenly destroyed.
They are completely swept away by terror!
speaker: Narrator

text:
As someone gets rid of a dream when he wakes up,
so you, O Lord, get rid of the thought of them
when you wake up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When my heart was filled with bitterness
and my mind was seized with envy,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was stupid, and I did not understand.
I was like a dumb animal in your presence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet, I am always with you.
You hold on to my right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With your advice you guide me,
and in the end you will take me to glory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As long as I have you,
I don’t need anyone else in heaven or on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My body and mind may waste away,
but God remains the foundation of my life
and my inheritance forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without a doubt, those who are far from you will die.
You destroy all who are unfaithful to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Being united with God is my highest good.
I have made the Almighty Lord my refuge
so that I may report everything that he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why, O God, have you rejected us forever?
Why does your anger
smolder against the sheep in your care?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your congregation.
Long ago you made it your own.
You bought this tribe to be your possession.
This tribe is Mount Zion, where you have made your home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn your steps toward these pathetic ruins.
The enemy has destroyed everything in the holy temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your opponents have roared inside your meeting place.
They have set up their own emblems as symbols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Starting from its entrance, they hacked away
like a woodcutter in a forest.
speaker: Narrator

text: They smashed all its carved paneling with axes and hatchets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They burned your holy place to the ground.
They dishonored the place where you live among us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They said to themselves, “We will crush them.”
They burned every meeting place of God in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We no longer see miraculous signs.
There are no prophets anymore.
No one knows how long this will last.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long, O God, will the enemy insult us?
Will the enemy despise you forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you hold back your hand, especially your right hand?
Take your hands out of your pockets.
Destroy your enemies!
speaker: Narrator

text:
And yet, from long ago God has been my king,
the one who has been victorious throughout the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You stirred up the sea with your own strength.
You smashed the heads of sea monsters in the water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You crushed the heads of Leviathan
and gave them to the creatures of the desert for food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You opened the springs and brooks.
You dried up the ever-flowing rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The day and the night are yours.
You set the moon and the sun in their places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You determined all the boundaries of the earth.
You created summer and winter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember how the enemy insulted you, O Lord.
Remember how an entire nation of godless fools despised your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not hand over the soul of your dove to wild animals.
Do not forget the life of your oppressed people forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Consider your promise 
because every dark corner of the land is filled with violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let oppressed people come back in disgrace.
Let weak and needy people praise your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arise, O God!
Fight for your own cause!
Remember how godless fools insult you all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not forget the shouting of your opponents.
Do not forget the uproar made by those who attack you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We give thanks to you, O God; we give thanks.
You are present, and your miracles confirm that.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I choose the right time,
I will judge fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the earth and everyone who lives on it begin to melt,
I will make its foundations as solid as rock. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said to those who brag, “Don’t brag,”
and to wicked people,
“Don’t raise your weapons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t raise your weapons so proudly
or speak so defiantly.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God alone is the judge.
He punishes one person and rewards another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A cup is in the Lord’s hand.
(Its foaming wine is thoroughly mixed with spices.)
He will empty it,
and all the wicked people on earth
will have to drink every last drop.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will speak about your miracles forever.
I will make music to praise the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will destroy all the weapons of wicked people,
but the weapons of righteous people will be raised proudly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is known in Judah.
His name is great in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His tent is in Salem.
His home is in Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There he destroyed flaming arrows,
shields, swords, and weapons of war. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are the radiant one.
You are more majestic than the ancient mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Brave people were robbed.
They died.
None of the warriors were able to lift a hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At your stern warning, O God of Jacob,
chariot riders and horses were put to sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You alone must be feared!
Who can stand in your presence when you become angry?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From heaven you announced a verdict.
The earth was fearful and silent
speaker: Narrator

text:
when you rose to judge, O God,
when you rose to save every oppressed person on earth. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even angry mortals will praise you.
You will wear the remainder of their anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make vows to the Lord your God, and keep them.
Let everyone around him bring gifts to the one who must be feared.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cuts short the lives of influential people.
He terrifies the kings of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Loudly, I cried to God.
Loudly, I cried to God
so that he would open his ears to hear me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the day I was in trouble, I went to the Lord for help.
At night I stretched out my hands in prayer without growing tired.
Yet, my soul refused to be comforted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I sigh as I remember God.
I begin to lose hope as I think about him. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
(You keep my eyelids open.)
I am so upset that I cannot speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have considered the days of old,
the years long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I remember my song in the night
and reflect on it.
My spirit searches for an answer:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will the Lord reject me for all time?
Will he ever accept me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has his mercy come to an end forever?
Has his promise been canceled throughout every generation?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has God forgotten to be merciful?
Has he locked up his compassion because of his anger? Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, “It makes me feel sick
that the power of the Most High is no longer the same.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will remember the deeds of the Lord.
I will remember your ancient miracles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will reflect on all your actions
and think about what you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, your ways are holy!
What god is as great as our God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are the God who performs miracles.
You have made your strength known among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With your might you have defended your people,
the descendants of Jacob and Joseph. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
The water saw you, O God.
The water saw you and shook.
Even the depths of the sea trembled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The clouds poured out water.
The sky thundered.
Even your arrows flashed in every direction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sound of your thunder rumbled in the sky.
Streaks of lightning lit up the world.
The earth trembled and shook.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your road went through the sea.
Your path went through raging water,
but your footprints could not be seen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a shepherd, you led your people.
You had Moses and Aaron take them by the hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Open your ears to my teachings, my people.
Turn your ears to the words from my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will open my mouth to illustrate points.
I will explain what has been hidden long ago,
speaker: Narrator

text:
things that we have heard and known about,
things that our parents have told us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We will not hide them from our children.
We will tell the next generation
about the Lord’s power and great deeds
and the miraculous things he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He established written instructions for Jacob’s people.
He gave his teachings to Israel.
He commanded our ancestors to make them known to their children
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that the next generation would know them.
Children yet to be born would learn them.
They will grow up and tell their children
speaker: Narrator

text:
to trust God, to remember what he has done,
and to obey his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will not be like their ancestors,
a stubborn and rebellious generation.
Their hearts were not loyal.
Their spirits were not faithful to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men of Ephraim, well-equipped with bows and arrows,
turned and ran on the day of battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They had not been faithful to God’s promise.
They refused to follow his teachings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They forgot what he had done—
the miracles that he had shown them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In front of their ancestors he performed miracles
in the land of Egypt, in the fields of Zoan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He divided the sea and led them through it.
He made the waters stand up like a wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He guided them by a cloud during the day
and by a fiery light throughout the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He split rocks in the desert.
He gave them plenty to drink, an ocean of water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made streams come out of a rock.
He made the water flow like rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They continued to sin against him,
to rebel in the desert against the Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text: They deliberately tested God by demanding the food they craved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spoke against God by saying,
“Can God prepare a banquet in the desert?
speaker: Narrator

text:
True, he did strike a rock,
and water did gush out,
and the streams did overflow.
But can he also give us bread or provide us, his people, with meat?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Lord heard this, he became furious.
His fire burned against Jacob
and his anger flared up at Israel
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they did not believe God
or trust him to save them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In spite of that, he commanded the clouds above
and opened the doors of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rained manna down on them to eat
and gave them grain from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Humans ate the bread of the mighty ones,
and God sent them plenty of food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made the east wind blow in the heavens
and guided the south wind with his might.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rained meat down on them like dust,
birds like the sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made the birds fall in the middle of his camp,
all around his dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ate more than enough.
He gave them what they wanted,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but they still wanted more.
While the food was still in their mouths,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the anger of God flared up against them.
He killed their strongest men and slaughtered the best young men in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In spite of all this, they continued to sin,
and they no longer believed in his miracles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought their days to an end like a whisper in the wind.
He brought their years to an end in terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he killed some of them, the rest searched for him.
They turned from their sins and eagerly looked for God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They remembered that God was their rock,
that the Most High was their defender.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They flattered him with their mouths
and lied to him with their tongues.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their hearts were not loyal to him.
They were not faithful to his promise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he is compassionate.
He forgave their sin.
He did not destroy them.
He restrained his anger many times.
He did not display all of his fury.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He remembered that they were only flesh and blood,
a breeze that blows and does not return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How often they rebelled against him in the wilderness!
How often they caused him grief in the desert!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Again and again they tested God,
and they pushed the Holy One of Israel to the limit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They did not remember his power—
the day he freed them from their oppressor,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he performed his miraculous signs in Egypt,
his wonders in the fields of Zoan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He turned their rivers into blood
so that they could not drink from their streams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent a swarm of flies that bit them
and frogs that ruined them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gave their crops to grasshoppers
and their produce to locusts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He killed their vines with hail
and their fig trees with frost.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He let the hail strike their cattle
and bolts of lightning strike their livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent his burning anger, rage, fury, and hostility against them.
He sent an army of destroying angels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cleared a path for his anger.
He did not spare them.
He let the plague take their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He slaughtered every firstborn in Egypt,
the ones born in the tents of Ham when their fathers were young.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he led his own people out like sheep
and guided them like a flock through the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He led them safely.
They had no fear while the sea covered their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought them into his holy land,
to this mountain that his power had won.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He forced nations out of their way
and gave them the land of the nations as their inheritance.
He settled the tribes of Israel in their own tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They tested God Most High and rebelled against him.
They did not obey his written instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were disloyal and treacherous like their ancestors.
They were like arrows shot from a defective bow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They made him angry because of their illegal worship sites.
They made him furious because they worshiped idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When God heard, he became furious.
He completely rejected Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He abandoned his dwelling place in Shiloh,
the tent where he had lived among humans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He allowed his power to be taken captive
and handed his glory over to an oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He let swords kill his people.
He was furious with those who belonged to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire consumed his best young men,
so his virgins heard no wedding songs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His priests were cut down with swords.
The widows of his priests could not even weep for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord woke up like one who had been sleeping,
like a warrior sobering up from too much wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He struck his enemies from behind
and disgraced them forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rejected the tent of Joseph.
He did not choose the tribe of Ephraim,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but he chose the tribe of Judah,
Mount Zion which he loved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He built his holy place to be like the high heavens,
like the earth which he made to last for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose his servant David.
He took him from the sheep pens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought him from tending the ewes that had lambs
so that David could be the shepherd of the people of Jacob,
of Israel, the people who belonged to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With unselfish devotion David became their shepherd.
With skill he guided them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, the nations have invaded the land that belongs to you.
They have dishonored your holy temple.
They have left Jerusalem in ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have given the dead bodies of your servants
to the birds for food.
They have given the flesh of your godly ones
to the animals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have shed the blood of your people around Jerusalem
as though it were water.
There is no one to bury your people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have become a disgrace to our neighbors,
an object of ridicule and contempt to those around us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long, O Lord?
Will you remain angry forever?
Will your fury continue to burn like fire?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour your fury on the nations that do not know you,
on the kingdoms that have not called you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have devoured Jacob.
They have destroyed his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not hold the crimes of our ancestors against us.
Reach out to us soon with your compassion,
because we are helpless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Help us, O God, our savior, for the glory of your name.
Rescue us, and forgive our sins for the honor of your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should the nations be allowed to say,
“Where is their God?”
Let us watch as the nations learn
that there is punishment for shedding the blood of your servants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the groans of prisoners come into your presence.
With your powerful arm rescue those who are condemned to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay each one of our neighbors back
with seven times the number of insults they used to insult you, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then we, your people, the flock in your pasture,
will give thanks to you forever.
We will praise you throughout every generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Open your ears, O Shepherd of Israel,
the one who leads the descendants of Joseph like sheep,
the one who is enthroned over the angels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Appear in front of Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh.
Wake up your power, and come to save us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, restore us and smile on us
so that we may be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God, commander of armies, how long will you smolder in anger
against the prayer of your people?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You made them eat tears as food.
You often made them drink their own tears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You made us a source of conflict to our neighbors,
and our enemies made fun of us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, commander of armies, restore us and smile on us
so that we may be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You brought a vine from Egypt.
You forced out the nations and planted it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You cleared the ground for it
so that it took root and filled the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its shade covered the mountains.
Its branches covered the mighty cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It reached out with its branches to the Mediterranean Sea.
Its shoots reached the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did you break down the stone fences around this vine?
All who pass by are picking its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wild boars from the forest graze on it.
Wild animals devour it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, commander of armies, come back!
Look from heaven and see!
Come to help this vine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take care of what your right hand planted,
the son you strengthened for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The vine has been cut down and burned.
Let them be destroyed by the threatening look on your face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your power rest on the man you have chosen,
the son of man you strengthened for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then we will never turn away from you.
Give us life again, and we will call on you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God, commander of armies, restore us, and smile on us
so that we may be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing joyfully to God, our strength.
Shout happily to the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Begin a psalm, and strike a tambourine.
Play lyres and harps with their pleasant music.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blow the ram’s horn on the day of the new moon,
on the day of the full moon,
on our festival days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is a law for Israel,
a legal decision from the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the instructions God set in place for Joseph
when Joseph rose to power over Egypt. 
I heard a message I did not understand:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I removed the burden from his shoulder.
His hands were freed from the basket.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you were in trouble, you called out to me, and I rescued you.
I was hidden in thunder, but I answered you.
I tested your loyalty at the oasis of Meribah. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, my people, and I will warn you.
Israel, if you would only listen to me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Never keep any strange god among you.
Never worship a foreign god.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the Lord your God, the one who brought you out of Egypt.
Open your mouth wide, and I will fill it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But my people did not listen to me.
Israel wanted nothing to do with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So I let them go their own stubborn ways
and follow their own advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only my people would listen to me!
If only Israel would follow me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would quickly defeat their enemies.
I would turn my power against their foes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate the Lord would cringe in front of him,
and their time for punishment would last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I would feed Israel with the finest wheat
and satisfy them with honey from a rock.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
God takes his place in his own assembly.
He pronounces judgment among the gods:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long are you going to judge unfairly?
How long are you going to side with wicked people?” Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Defend weak people and orphans.
Protect the rights of the oppressed and the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue weak and needy people.
Help them escape the power of wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wicked people do not know or understand anything.
As they walk around in the dark,
all the foundations of the earth shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, “You are gods.
You are all sons of the Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will certainly die like humans
and fall like any prince.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arise, O God!
Judge the earth, because all the nations belong to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, do not remain silent.
Do not turn a deaf ear to me.
Do not keep quiet, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, your enemies are in an uproar.
Those who hate you hold their heads high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They make plans in secret against your people
and plot together against those you treasure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, “Let’s wipe out their nation
so that the name of Israel will no longer be remembered.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They agree completely on their plan.
They form an alliance against you:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the tents from Edom and Ishmael,
Moab and Hagar,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gebal, Ammon, and Amalek,
Philistia, along with those who live in Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even Assyria has joined them.
They helped the descendants of Lot. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do to them what you did to Midian,
to Sisera and Jabin at the Kishon River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were destroyed at Endor.
They became manure to fertilize the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Treat their influential people as you treated Oreb and Zeeb.
Treat all their leaders like Zebah and Zalmunna.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “Let’s take God’s pasturelands for ourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my God, blow them away like tumbleweeds,
like husks in the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pursue them with your storms,
and terrify them with your windstorms
speaker: Narrator

text:
the way fire burns a forest
and flames set mountains on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let their faces blush with shame, O Lord,
so that they must look to you for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them be put to shame and terrified forever.
Let them die in disgrace
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that they must acknowledge you.
Your name is the Lord.
You alone are the Most High God of the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your dwelling place is lovely, O Lord of Armies!
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul longs and yearns
for the Lord’s courtyards.
My whole body shouts for joy to the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even sparrows find a home,
and swallows find a nest for themselves.
There they hatch their young
near your altars, O Lord of Armies, my king and my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed are those who live in your house.
They are always praising you. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed are those who find strength in you.
Their hearts are on the road that leads to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As they pass through a valley where balsam trees grow,
they make it a place of springs.
The early rains cover it with blessings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their strength grows as they go along
until each one of them appears
in front of God in Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God, commander of armies, hear my prayer.
Open your ears, O God of Jacob. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at our shield, O God.
Look with favor on the face of your anointed one.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One day in your courtyards is better than a thousand anywhere else.
I would rather stand in the entrance to my God’s house
than live inside wicked people’s homes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord God is a sun and shield.
The Lord grants favor and honor.
He does not hold back any blessing
from those who live innocently.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord of Armies, blessed is the person who trusts you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You favored your land, O Lord.
You restored the fortunes of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You removed your people’s guilt.
You pardoned all their sins. Selah
speaker: Narrator

text:
You laid aside all your fury.
You turned away from your burning anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Restore us, O God, our savior.
Put an end to your anger against us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you be angry with us forever?
Will you ever let go of your anger in the generations to come?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Won’t you restore our lives again
so that your people may find joy in you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Show us your mercy, O Lord,
by giving us your salvation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I want to hear what God the Lord says,
because he promises peace to his people, to his godly ones.
But they must not go back to their stupidity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, his salvation is near those who fear him,
and his glory will remain in our land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mercy and truth have met.
Righteousness and peace have kissed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truth sprouts from the ground,
and righteousness looks down from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will certainly give us what is good,
and our land will produce crops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteousness will go ahead of him
and make a path for his steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn your ear toward me, O Lord.
Answer me, because I am oppressed and needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Protect me, because I am faithful to you.
Save your servant who trusts you. You are my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have pity on me, O Lord,
because I call out to you all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give me joy, O Lord,
because I lift my soul to you.
